clinical_study.brief_title: Recurrence of Liver Malignancy After Ischemia/Reperfusion Injury
clinical_study.official_title: Does Vascular Occlusion in Liver Resections Predispose to Recurrence of Malignancy in the Liver Remnant Due to Ischemia/Reperfusion Injury?

brief_summary.textblock: Severe ischemic changes of the liver remnant after hepatectomy could expedite tumor recurrence on the residual liver. Our study aimed at assessing the effect of warm ischemic/reperfusion (I/R) injuries on surgery-to-local recurrence interval and patient overall survival, during major hepatectomies under inflow and outflow vascular control.

detailed_description.textblock: One hundred and eighteen patients were subjected to liver resection under total inflow and outflow vascular clamping and were assigned as study group. These individuals were retrospectively matched to 112 counterparts, who underwent liver surgery applying inflow and outflow vascular clamping only of the segment harboring the tumor, sparing the liver remnant from any I/R injury (control group). The two cohorts were compared regarding recurrence-free survival and overall survival.

primary_outcome.time_frame: from time of operation until time of malignant recurrence, assessed up to 15 years
from time of operation until time of death, assessed up to 20 years

arm_group.description: patients subjected to major hepatectomy with vascular control of blood inflow and outflow of the whole liver
patients subjected to major hepatectomy by selectively clamping the portal and hepatic vessels only of the lobe harboring the tumor

intervention.description: major hepatectomy with vascular control of blood inflow and outflow of the whole liver
major liver resection by selectively clamping the portal and hepatic vessels only of the lobe harboring the tumor

study_pop.textblock: retrospective analysis of an internal hepatectomy database
